Award.AwardTitle: Linear and Nonlinear Stability for Infinite-Dimensional Dynamical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal focuses on the stability of waves for several models both in one and higher spatial dimensions. The common feature of these equations is that they can be viewed as dynamical systems on an infinite-dimensional space. These Hamiltonian PDEs support coherent structures such as solitary waves as well as periodic wave solutions. The PI will address open questions by developing a systematic approach to the spectral stability of waves for second order in time PDEs. An advantage of this method is that it treats both spatially periodic and solitary waves, which provides a link between the well studied results for solitary waves and the mostly open questions on periodic waves. These models are at the frontiers of current research and present lots of challenges at the spectral and linear stability level, but virtually nothing is known for their asymptotic stability.

The PI studies will provide for better theoretical understanding of various nonlinear systems such as the beam equation, water waves and the Klein-Gordon model. Any progress on these questions will not only be important mathematically, but will find immediate applications in physical sciences. The PI will train the future researches by working with graduate and undergraduate students on the topics of the proposal. A special freshman seminar on nonlinear waves is being designed by the PI as part of a pilot First Year Seminar program at the University of Kansas. The PI has worked with students from local schools and is the main organizer for several mathematics competitions for school age kids. The students preparing for the competitions have been exposed to applied mathematics problems and have gained a better understanding of the role mathematics plays in modeling real life phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI used spectral theory and semigroups methods, as well as techniques of Fourier analysis, to study several outstanding open problems in the stability theory for Hamiltonian PDEs. More specifically, the spectral stability of waves for some water-wave equations, sine-Gordon and Klein-Gordon equations as well as the periodic solutions of a fourth-order nonlinear beam equation.  The work focuses on the linear stability of  waves for several models both in one and higher spatial dimensions. Stanislavova and collaborators have developed a systematic approach to the spectral stability of waves for second order in time PDEs. An advantage of this method is that it treats both spatially periodic and solitary waves equally well, which provides a link between the well studied results for solitary waves and many open questions on periodic waves. Important examples here are the Boussinesq system and the short pulse equation, but also sine-Gordon and Klein-Gordon equations. These problems are at the frontiers of current research and present lots of challenges at the spectral and linear stability level, but virtually nothing is known for their asymptotic stability. The PI studies also the long-time behavior and nonlinear stability of waves for these models.  Of interest is the relation between linear and nonlinear stability, in particular for wave equations where the generators for the semigroups are operator matrices whose spectrum is not easy to compute. The common feature of these equations is that they support soliton-like solutions, such as ground or excited states, solitary or periodic traveling or standing waves and the asymptotic behavior of these systems is of great importance for many practical applications.

During the award period, the PI and Stefanov have developed an abstract theory to treat the linear stability of certain special solutions of second order in time evolutionary PDE. In a series of papers, the method was improved and generalized and subsequently applied to standing waves of the following problems: the Klein-Gordon equation - both ground states and certain excited states, the Klein-Gordon-Zakharov system and the beam equation. Applications to   excited states for the Klein-Gordon model as well as multidimensional traveling waves (not necessarily homoclinic to zero) for general second order equations of this type are possible in such general setting. In all cases the abstract results provide a complete characterization of the linear stability of such solutions. Other problems resolved during the duration of the award include the transeverse instability of certain periodic solutions  of the Kadomtsev-Petviashvili-I equation and the nonlinear Schrodinger equation, the introduction of PT-symmetric terms in the context of classical Klein-Gordon field theories and the implication of such terms on the spectral stability of coherent structures, namely kinks. the PI and Demirkaya study numerically the existence and stability of special solutions of the nonlinear beam equation. Examples are the standing wave solutions and traveling wave solutions. For both types of solutions, numerical results for the bounds for the frequency and wave speeds that divide the intervals of stability and the intervals of instability are presented. This is of practical interest since these waves can only be shown to exist as minimizers of a variational problem rather than written in explicit form. Thus the spectral information and the stability index can be computed numerically. 

The PI worked on training graduate and undergraduate students in the areas discussed in this proposal and participated in numerous conferences and events where dissemination of the results takes place. A Ph.D. student, Aslihan Demirkaya, has worked with the PI on the questions posed above and has given several talks at conferences on her results. Demirkaya graduated and is currently assistant professor at University of Hartford. The PI has co-organized a mini symposium during the AMS sectional meeting at the University in Kansas in 2012. The PI guest-edited a special volume on stability of special solutions for PDEs in Discrete and Continuous Dynamical Systems - S. Aslo, the PI has been involved in the organization of various math competitions and events for school aged kids. In particular this PI has been the state coordinator for the International Math Kangaroo competition for the state of Kansas.
